Symptoms

Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS)

Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis

CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

Acute Arsenic Poisoning

Dermal

questions.text: Identify the given plant based on its features
questions.explanation:
Argemone Mexicana (Prickly Poppy)

Toxic Parts

Entire plant; seeds resemble mustard seeds but are darker with minute projections.

Toxic Oil

Argemone oil (katkar oil) causes epidemic dropsy.

Active Principles

Plant Alkaloids: Berberine, Protopine.

Oil Alkaloids: Sanguinarine, Dihydrosanguinarine. (Cause abnormal blood vessel permeability.)

General Symptoms

Gradual onset with appetite loss, diarrhea, leg edema, and generalized anasarca.

System-Specific Signs

Heart: Myocardial damage, heart dilatation.

CVS: Hypotension, breathlessness, feeble pulse.

Hepatic: Enlarged, tender liver.

PNS: Tingling, hyperesthesia, calf muscle tenderness, reduced or absent jerks.

Ocular: Dim vision due to increased intraocular pressure.

Skin: Bluish mottling from peripheral vessel dilation.

Fatal Outcome

Severe heart damage.

Treatment

Balanced diet, decontamination, cessation of oil consumption, diuretics, corticosteroids, and supportive care.

Medico-Legal Aspects

Argemone oil is commonly used to adulterate mustard or other edible oils.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Supportive treatment

Gastric lavage, airway, breathing, and circulation management (intravenous fluids, cardiac monitoring, etc.).

Medical treatment

Freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide (chemical antidote)

Chelating agents
  • BAL (Dimercaprol)
  • DMSA (Dimercapto succinic acid) or DMPS (Dimercapto propane sulfonic acid)
  • Penicillamine

Other measures
  • Purgatives like Castor oil or Magnesium sulfate (remove unabsorbed poison from the intestine).
  • Glucose-saline with sodium bicarbonate.
  • Hemodialysis or exchange transfusion.

 

Acute Arsenic Poisoning

questions.text: Which of these is not a cardiac poison?

Gastric lavage, commonly known as stomach pumping or gastric irrigation, is a procedure performed to remove the contents of the stomach. It has been widely used since the early 19th century as a standard method to eliminate toxins from the stomach. This procedure is typically employed for individuals who have consumed poison or overdosed on substances like ethanol. Additionally, it may be performed prior to surgery to empty the digestive tract. In which of the following situations is gastric lavage not recommended?
questions.explanation:
Step

Details

Patient Positioning

Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration

Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum

Tube Placement Confirmation

Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds

Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea)

Fluid Administration

Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube

Fluid Selection

Tap water for most cases

Normal saline for infants

Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons

Residual Fluid

Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison

Complication

Details

Aspiration

Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury

Esophageal/Gastric Perforation

Can be life-threatening

Tube Misplacement

Misplaced into trachea, causing complications

Bleeding

Can occur with improper technique or pathology

Alternative

Description

Emetics

Induce vomiting in conscious patients

Dilution

Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances

Endoscopic/Surgical Removal

Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

questions.text: In case of corrosive acid ingestion, stomach is opened along the?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Greater curvatu

Organ

Dissection Method

Key Features

Brain

Cerebrum

  • It is separated from the cerebellum and brainstem with a horizontal cut.
  • Sliced coronally at 1 cm intervals.
  • Fixed brains sliced through mammillary bodies, then coronally.
  • Asymmetry, brain shift, old infarcts, focal lesions, ventricle dilation, cortex shrinkage, fat emboli, petechial hemorrhage, and edema.

Cerebellum

  • Horizontally dissected in a ‘fan’ shape.
  • Middle slice through the dentate nucleus.
  • Structural abnormalities such as hemorrhages and lesions.

Brainstem

  • Sliced perpendicular to its axis at 5 mm intervals.
  • Hemorrhages, softening, cystic degeneration, and tumors.

Heart

Inflow-outflow

  • Open the right atrium, tricuspid valve, and pulmonic valve.
  • Open left atrium, mitral valve, and aortic valve.
  • Best for systematic chamber and valve evaluation.

Ventricular Slicing

  • First, slice 3 cm from the apex.
  • Parallel slices 1 cm apart.
  • Rest opened along with blood flow.
  • Useful for suspected ischemic myocardial disease, shows infarction distribution.

Sandwich Technique

  • The knife slices the left ventricle muscle.
  • The myocardium opened like a book.
  • Exposes infarcts or fibrotic plaques in the myocardium.

Spinal Cord

Posterior Approach

  • Long midline incision, flap skin and muscle outward.
  • Posterior arch cut with a saw.
  • Remove spinal processes and laminae.
  • Open dura and cut nerves for spinal cord removal.
  • Lesions along the spinal cord and surrounding tissues.

Intestine
  • The entire length is dissected.
  • Injuries, poison reactions, foreign bodies (bullets), ulcerative colitis-like lesions (mercuric chloride poisoning).

Liver
  • Remove and weigh.
  • Multiple transverse sections 1–2 cm apart.
  • Hepatomegaly (inflammation, neoplasia) or shrunken liver (cirrhosis). Gallbladder pathology (stones, inflammation).

questions.text: A patient with Pink color skin & mucosa, a bitter almond smell from breath, and frothy discharge. The cause of death is:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - HCN poisoning

Cyanide poisoning

Physical Appearance
  • Gaseous state- Hydrogen cyanide (HCN)
  • Liquid form- Hydrocyanic acid or Prussic acid
  • Solid state- salt forms

Sources of poisoning
  • Electroplating, photographic processes, rubber, and plastic manufacturing industries
  • Insecticide and rodenticide
  • Drug toxicity: Sodium nitroprusside
  • Military chemical warfare agents
  • Burning of plastic furniture, silk, or wool
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Bitter almonds, peach, apricot, plum, apple, pear, cassava

Mode of Action
  • Rapid absorption across both skin and mucous membrane
  • Cyanide salts combine with hydrochloric acid in the stomach to form HCN that is absorbed
  • Inhibition of cytochrome oxidase causes histotoxic anoxia
  • Neurotoxicity

Clinical Features
  • Inhalation: Dizziness, vertigo, and constriction of the throat
  • Ingestion: Nausea, headache, loss of muscular power, hypotension, cardiovascular failure, and convulsion
  • Skin: Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes
  • Anion gap metabolic acidosis and lactic acidosis

Diagnosis
  • Lee-Jones test
  • Serum cyanide level

Treatment
  • Severe acidosis (pH < 7.1): Administer sodium bicarbonate
  • Antidotal therapy (Eli Lilly cyanide kit approach)
    • First step: Inhalation of Amyl nitrite
    • Second step: Sodium nitrite (3% solution) IV
    • Third step: Sodium thiosulfate (25% solution) IV
  • Other Antidotes
    • 4-dimethylaminophenol (4-DMAP)
    • Hydroxocobalamin (Vitamin B12): Combines with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted in the urine
    • Hyperbaric oxygen
  • Note: Methylene blue is NOT an antidote for cyanide and must NOT be used

Autopsy Findings
  • Bitter almond’s odour
  • Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes
  • Cyanosis of extremities
  • Hemorrhagic gastritis
  • Disseminated petechiae in brain, meninges, pleura, lungs, and pericardium
  • Pulmonary and cerebral edema

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the image shown below?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

options.label: C
options.text: Atropine is not specific for aconite poisoning

questions.correct_answer: A. Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
questions.explanation:
Species

Aconitum napellus, Aconitum ferox

Synonyms

Monk’s hood, mitha zaher, bish, wolf’s bane, women’s bane, devil’s helmet, or blue rocket

Source
  • All parts of the plant are poisonous (Option A)
  • Root and root tubers are the most potent (often mistaken for horseradish root)
  • Grown in Mountainous areas of the northern hemisphere. Eg. Sub Himalayan range (Option D ruled out)

Active Principles

Aconitine, pseudo-aconitine, indaconitine, picraconitine, aconine.

Mechanism of Action

Affects voltage-sensitive sodium channels, stimulates then paralyzes sensory nerves, secretory nerves, CNS, and myocardium.

Symptoms (by system)
  • GIT: Nausea, vomiting, salivation, abdominal pain, diarrhea, burning/tingling of mouth, tongue, throat, followed by numbness.
  • CVS: Hypotension, AV block, bradycardia, chest pain, ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, slow/feeble pulse. (Option B ruled out)
  • CNS: Vertigo, restlessness, headache, giddiness.
  • MS: Muscle weakness, twitching, spasms.
  • RS: Slow, labored, shallow breathing.
  • Ocular: Alternating pupil dilation/contraction (hippus), diplopia, impaired vision.
  • Others: Subnormal temperature, cold skin, yellow-green vision, tinnitus, paralysis of facial muscles.
  • Death: Respiratory failure or ventricular fibrillation.

Fatal Dose

Root: 1-2 g

Treatment
  • No specific antidote.
  • Gastric lavage with tannic acid/activated charcoal.
  • Inotropic therapy for hypotension, atropine for bradycardia. (Option C ruled out)
  • Ventricular arrhythmia treated with amiodarone, flecainide; cardiopulmonary bypass for refractory cases.

Medico-legal Aspects
  • Ideal homicidal poison: cheap, easily available, small lethal dose, short fatal period, difficult to detect postmortem.
  • Accidental poisoning: mistaken for horseradish

  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

Option Explanation Seen after atropine?
Bradycardia Reversed by atropine (muscarinic blockade) Not seen
Muscle weakness Nicotinic effect; not reversed by atropine Seen
Diaphoresis Muscarinic effect; reversed by atropine Seen before, improves
Nasal discharge Muscarinic effect; reversed by atropine Seen before, improves

questions.text: A young teenage boy with a history of drug abuse had been instilled with a shot of intravenous cocaine at a party. He is rushed to the emergency room by his friends. Some of the symptoms were diaphoresis, headache, and acute coronary spasm. Which of the following symptoms noted would go against the likely diagnosis of cocaine poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Bradycardia

Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless (Option D)
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate (Option B)
  • Increase in temperature (Option C)
  • Rapid and deep respiration

 

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction (Option A)
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted: Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

questions.correct_answer: A. Atropine and neostigmine are very useful in the management of krait bite
questions.explanation:
First Aid: ‘ CARRY NO RIGHT ’

CARRY
  • Do not allow the victim to walk on their own, must be carried (in any form) to the hospital as soon as possible.

NO
  • No Suction
  • No Cautery
  • No Ligature
  • No Tourniquet

RIGHT
  • R: Reassure the patient
  • I: Immobilize the limb: by application of crepe bandages (Sutherland wraps)
  • GH: Get to the Hospital immediately
  • T: Tell history/symptoms

Pressure bandage
  • Used for immobilization of the limb by application of crepe bandage - known as Sutherland wraps.
  • Contraindicated in viper bites.
  • Ideal pressure: 50-70 mm Hg.

ASV
  • Mainstay of treatment.
  • Used only when signs of systemic poisoning are present
  • Polyvalent anti snake venom (PAV) used in India can neutralize (i) Cobra (ii) Krait (iii) Russel viper (iv) Saw-scaled viper bites.
  • Dose: 1-2 ml/kg (!0 vials) irrespective of sex/age.
  • Each vial: neutralizes 6-8 mg of snake venom
  • Test dose is not required/advised to be given before initiating ASV.
  • Ideally to be given within 4 hours of snake bite.
  • To be given until clinical improvement (in cobra bites)/ Clotting time becomes normal (in viper bites).

Adjuvant treatment
  • Neostigmine 1.5mg: for neuroparalytic symptoms (cobra bite).
  • Atropine 0.5mg: To antagonize muscarinic actions of Ach.
  • Surgical debridement and FFP may be required in Viper bites.

  • Nasal septum ulceration.

questions.text: In cases of alcohol abuse, in what substance is the blood typically preserved during an autopsy?
questions.explanation:
Specimen

Importance

Blood

Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination.

Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, fluoride/oxalate, if alcohol is suspected

 

Urine

Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons.

Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is

Suspected (Option A)

 

Gastric Contents

Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.(Option D)

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid (Option C)

.

Liver

Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison. Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Hair and Nails

Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns.

Scene Residues

Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers.

questions.explanation:
Management

Details

Indications/Notes

First Aid
  • Do not allow the victim to walk (Carry)
  • Avoid tourniquets, except in specific cases(No)
  • Reassure patient
  • Immobilize bitten limb (Option B)
  • Transport to the hospital quickly
  • Tell the doctor about any systemic symptoms

Tourniquets only for severe elapid/sea snake bites with >0.5h but <2-3h transport time

Evaluation
  • Check for signs of envenomation
  • Monitor vital signs
  • Perform 20-minute whole blood clotting time
  • Check coagulation profile, CPK, renal function

Incoagulable blood indicates systemic envenomation by Viperidae

Antivenom Therapy
  • Mild: 50 ml
  • Moderate: 50-100 ml
  • Severe: 150-200 ml

Effective against the 4 most important venomous snakes in India, namely, Cobra, Common Krait, Russell's viper and saw-scaled viper.

Indications:

  • Haemostatic abnormalities
  • Neurotoxicity
  • Cardiovascular dysfunction
  • Impaired consciousness
  • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Extensive local swelling

Antivenom Administration (Option A)
  • Dilute in 5 ml/kg body weight of isotonic saline/5% Dextrose
  • Infuse over 1-2 hours
  • Monitor for hypersensitivity reactions

Repeat if severe signs persist after 1-2 hours or if coagulability is not restored within 6 hours

Supportive Care
  • Tetanus prophylaxis
  • Antibiotics (if severe local reaction)
  • Manage respiratory paralysis
  • Fresh frozen plasma/cryoprecipitates for severe bleeding

Avoid heparin, corticosteroids, and EDTA.

Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had an arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Source

Seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica and other species of Strychnos plants found in India.

Mechanism of action

  • Stimulates all parts of the central nervous system, especially the anterior horn cells. Greatly increases reflex excitability by removing normal inhibition of motor cell stimulation, causing widespread uncontrolled motor activity of the spinal cord.
  • Slight stimuli like noise, light, or a breeze can cause violent generalized muscle spasms

Clinical Features
  • Opisthotonos- arched body with only the back of head and heels touching the ground:
  • Emprosthotonos- forward curve
  • Pleurothotonus- sideways curve
  • Risus sardonicus- fixed grin:

Treatment
  • Immediate Care: Place in a dark, quiet room.
  • Anesthesia: Chloroform or intravenous barbiturate if spasms allow.
  • Adsorption: Administer animal charcoal to absorb free strychnine, or tannic acid if charcoal is unavailable.
  • Antidotes: Intravenous barbiturates to stop convulsions.
  • Muscle relaxants: Mephenesin, intravenous diazepam for anticonvulsant effects.

Autopsy Findings
  • Rigor mortis: Sets in almost immediately and passes off early.
  • Stomach contents: Remains of seeds may be found.
  • Delayed putrefaction.
  • Toxicological analysis: Strychnine can be detected in putrefied bodies and viscera; brain and spinal cord should be preserved for analysis.

Differentiating Points

Strychnine Poisoning

Tetanus

1. History

History of poisoning

History of injury

2. Onset

Sudden onset

Gradual onset

3. Convulsions/Spasms

Generalized convulsions

Lockjaw (trismus)

4. Chest Movement

Chest fixed during convulsions

Not typically fixed

5. Relaxation Between Spasms

Complete relaxation between seizures

Relaxation between spasms is never complete

6. Duration Until Fatality

Ends fatally within a few hours

Death is rare within a few hours

7. Chemical Evidence

Chemical analysis reveals the poison

No specific chemical detection

Eli Lilly antidote Kit (3-step approach)
  1. Amyl nitrate: Oxidises haemoglobin to methemoglobin, which scavenges cyanide.
  2. Sodium nitrate: causes cyanide to detach from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase.
    • Amyl nitrate is used as a temporary measure until IV Sodium nitrate can be given.
  3. Sodium thiosulphate:It activates an enzyme that converts cyanide to a less toxic agent, thiocyanate.

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium, hypotension, and constricted pinpoint pupils. Which of the following is likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Introduction
  • Dried extract from the poppy plant (Papaver somniferum)

Extraction
  • Obtained by vertical incisions from unripe poppy capsule (toxic part)

Toxic principles
  • Phenanthrene group: Morphine, Codeine and Thebaine
  • Benzylisoquinoline group: Papaverine and Noscapine

Mechanism of action (MOA)
  • Exhibits action via 3 receptors mainly - Mu(μ), Delta(δ) and Kappa(κ) receptors and release Endorphins.
  • Addictive potential is due to its action on Mu(μ) and Delta(δ) receptors
  • Action on Kappa(κ) receptor causes dysphoria - no addictive potential

Effects
  • Tolerability, Addiction, Dysphoria (κ-receptor)
  • Pruritus is a common adverse effect.
  • Other effects: Constipation, Respiratory depression, Urinary retention.
  • Tolerability is developed for all actions except: 3 C's
    • Constipation
    • Convulsions
    • Constriction of pupils (Miosis)

Fatal dose

Opium: 2 g

Morphine: 0.2 g

Codeine: 80 mg

Fatal period: 6-12 hours

Management

  • Support vitals: Use a respirator and other emergency procedures.
  • Decontamination:
    • Stomach wash with 1:5000 KMnO₄, leaving some solution in the stomach to oxidize any secreted alkaloid.
    • Perform lavage even after IV/IM drug injection, as it is secreted in the stomach.
    • Administer activated charcoal as the primary decontamination method.
    • Enema with sodium sulfate twice daily.
    • Whole-bowel irrigation for body packers.
  • Antidote:
    • Naloxone

Common Name

Mechanism of Action

Atropa belladonna

Deadly Nightshade

Contains alkaloids (e.g., atropine) that block muscarinic receptors, leading to anticholinergic effects.

Digitalis purpurea

Foxglove

Contains cardiac glycosides (e.g., digoxin) that inhibit Na+/K+ ATPase, leading to increased intracellular calcium and positive inotropic effects on the heart.

Taxus baccata

Yew

Contains taxine alkaloids that inhibit sodium channels, leading to cardiac conduction disturbances.

Amanita phalloides

Death Cap

Contains amatoxins that inhibit RNA polymerase II, leading to liver and kidney toxicity.

Ricinus communis

Castor Bean

Contains ricin, a potent cytotoxin that inhibits protein synthesis by inactivating ribosomes.

Nerium oleander

Oleander

Contains cardiac glycosides (e.g., oleandrin) that have similar effects to digitalis glycosides, causing cardiac toxicity.

Colchicum autumnale

Autumn Crocus

Contains colchicine that inhibits microtubule polymerization, leading to cellular dysfunction and disruption of mitosis.

Datura stramonium

Jimsonweed

Contains alkaloids (e.g., scopolamine) that block muscarinic receptors, causing anticholinergic effects.

Dieffenbachia

Dumb Cane

Contains calcium oxalate crystals that cause mechanical irritation and tissue inflammation upon contact.

Rhus radicans

Poison Ivy/Oak/Sumac

Contains urushiol oil that causes allergic contact dermatitis upon contact with the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - P

Mechanism

Explanation

Scorpion Venom

Scorpion venom contains various neurotoxins that stimulate the sympathetic nervous system, leading to increased release of norepinephrine (a neurotransmitter) and subsequent activation of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors.

Prazosin

Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist, meaning it blocks the binding of norepinephrine to these receptors. By inhibiting the activation of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, prazosin counteracts the vasoconstriction and other sympathetic responses caused by excessive sympathetic stimulation from scorpion venom.

Effect

The blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors by prazosin results in vasodilation (relaxation of blood vessels), which helps to lower blood pressure.

questions.text: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Huffing

Methods of substance abuse Explanation
Bagging Bagging refers to a method of inhaling substances by placing them inside a bag and then inhaling or breathing in the vapors. The bag is typically held over the nose and mouth, allowing the person to inhale the substance contained within the bag
Snorting Snorting involves the inhalation of powdered substances, typically drugs, through the nose. The substance is crushed into a fine powder and then snorted through the nostrils using a straw, rolled-up paper, or other devices.
Sniffing Sniffing refers to the act of inhaling or smelling substances, often volatile or aromatic substances.
Huffing Huffing involves the deliberate inhalation of volatile substances or inhalants directly from their container or source. The person typically places their mouth or nose directly on the container and inhales deeply, allowing the vapors or fumes to enter their respiratory system. This method is associated with the misuse of chemicals, solvents, or other volatile substances for recreational purposes.
